awd_abstract_narration:
Geometric flows have many real-world applications including material sciences, biology and image processing. Mathematically they are parabolic partial differential equations that deform geometric objects to their optimal shapes. In addition to their importance in geometric analysis, they also have potential applications to other mathematical disciplines, such as mathematical physics and low-dimensional topology. This award supports the investigation of two fundamental examples of geometric flows, mean curvature flow and Ricci flow. The PI will develop new ideas and robust techniques that will benefit the study of other geometric partial differential equations and related applications. In addition, the PI will place a strong emphasis on education in differential geometry and related topics through teaching, supervising undergraduate, graduate students and young scholars, and organizing seminars and conferences. The PI will also play an important role in the promotion of women and other underrepresented groups in STEM to enhance diversity and equity in the society.

The first part of the project is on the properties of closed hypersurfaces with low entropy. It involves an exploration of global features of the moduli space of asymptotically conical self-expanders of mean curvature flow. An overarching goal is to verify the smooth four-dimensional Schoenflies conjecture for hypersurfaces with low entropy. The second part concerns the variational construction of new examples of asymptotically conical self-expanders. The third part probes the asymptotic structure of soliton solutions to mean curvature flow as well as Ricci flow. The PI aims to show the geometry of these soliton solutions under mild topological restrictions is bounded in various senses.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Mean curvature flow is a basic example of curvature flows of submanifolds in a Riemannian manifold. In general, a mean curvature flow will develop singularities in finite time. A central topic in the study of mean curvature flow is to understand the asymptotic behavior of the flow near a given singularity. It is known that self-similar solutions to mean curvature flow play a crucial role in the singularity analysis. 

In a series of joint work with Jacob Bernstein (Johns Hopkins University), the PI defined a notion of relative entropy motivated by self-similarly expanding solutions to mean curvature flow (or self-expanders), and proved the relative entropy is monotone under a mean curvature flow emerging from a cone-like singularity. Together with Bernstein, the PI established a mountain-pass theorem for self-expanders in the obstacle setting and studied the gradient flow for the relative expander entropy. As an application, they verified the 4-dimensional smooth Schoenflies conjecture for closed hypersurfaces with small Colding-Minicozzi entropy. The PI has also made significant progress towards the classification of asymptotic structure for translating surfaces for mean curvature flow. 

The PI has devoted herself to building an inclusive and welcoming community. Integrated into the projects above, the PI taught graduate courses and co-organize seminars on topics of the projects to attract young people to the field. The PI has also mentored several undergraduate and graduate students, as well as a postdoctoral scholar on related research questions. This includes one graduate student solving conjectures of Bernstein and finishing an excellent PhD thesis; one undergraduate student going on for graduate study in differential geometry; one postdoctoral scholar landing a tenure-track job at an internationally recognized university.
